letters.summarized4Sentences: Susan updates Rachel on Mrs. Stanton's plans to remain until after the convention, meaning her position cannot be filled this time. She mentions a report saying Susan is anxious to supersede Stanton. Dansville and Hempstead are mentioned as places they will visit. Susan expresses her desire to secure hearings with Congressional Committees.

There is mention of Susan's desire to take Stanton's position. Plans to visit Dansville and Hempstead are discussed. The appeal for money for South Dakota is also mentioned.

letters.summarized4Sentences: Susan B. Anthony is writing to Rachel Foster Avery regarding the National-American Woman Suffrage Association's Programs for Hearings and Conventions. Anthony questions whether the majority of the Program Com. need to vote on who should be invited to speak. She encourages Avery to decide who is best for the job, take action, and get those people to prepare. She further discusses philosophy, titles for speakers and their papers, and mentions some speakers who might speak on women in the industries. Anthony asks Avery if there are any points that she wants her to talk about at a coming event, and if she wants Anthony to proclaim her purpose to have her name placed alongside Elizabeth Cady Stanton's on the top of the letterhead.

Anthony encourages Avery to decide who is best for the job, take action, and get those people to prepare. She further discusses philosophy, titles for speakers and their papers, and mentions some speakers who might speak on women in the industries.

letters.summarized4Sentences: Susan B. Anthony writes to Anna letting her know that she is catching up on letters after Mrs. Harper has kept her close to chapter work. She also mentions writing a letter to Anna Gordon pleading with her to not be hurried into writing Miss Willard's biography. She also mentions the difficulty of rushing and half digesting the writing of the 50 chapters before Mrs. Harper leaves, and mentions fundraising for the Temple. Anthony also mentions accepting an invitation to speak at the Thousand Island Park Willard Meeting.

letters.summarized4Sentences: Susan had an interview with Senator Blair regarding a hearing, but the earliest date possible would be Jan. 13th. She is planning on asking Mrs. Sargent and Mrs. Knox Goodrich of California, Mrs. Hallowell and Mrs. Willis of Rochester to help pull down contributions. Susan informs Rachel that Phoebe is there and she thinks that the Program Committee should make a place for her to speak at one of the evening sessions. Additionally, Mrs. Colby has arrived and plans on sending off her Nov. 20 paper.

letters.summarized4Sentences: Susan B. Anthony writes to Mrs Gage to seek her help concerning Mrs Stanton's assertion that the legislature is above counts and constitutions. She states her view regarding Mrs Stanton's position as absurd and ridiculous, and that she does not want her name to stand to it as now stated. In the letter, Susan B. Anthony urges Mrs Gage to make the assertion express the fact, and so state it that she can see it.

Anthony urges Mrs Gage to make the assertion express the fact, and so state it that she can see it.

letters.summery4Sentences: Susan B. Anthony agrees with Madam Anneke's plan of protest and demand for women to be enfranchised. She wants the protest to focus solely on women's demand for civil and political equality of rights and not to be mixed up with or become one of 19 other points of protest. Anthony suggests the National Woman Suffrage Association should take at least half of the cost of printing the document for the Memorial. Anthony is sure Matilda Joslyn Gage is the right one to write the protest letter.

Andrews' letter of July 19th, 1892, stating that in his opinion, the present law does not differentiate between sexes in terms of qualifications for voting for school commissioners. He cited Chapter 9. Laws 1890, Chapter 214. Laws 1892, and Chapter 655. Laws 1886. Mrs. Cleveland was the first to receive such a definite reply.

letters.summarized4Sentences: Susan B. Anthony writes to Rachel about a claim that needs to be made and suggests entrusting it with Judge Mallon. She also talks about the possibility of carrying the vote in South Dakota next November. She mentions the Republicans made Prohibition assent a plank in their platform and if they do it for woman suffrage assent, the question will be carried. She also talks about the success of the suffrage committee in keeping all 2nd Partism out of the slate.

Washington D.C.
Feb. 5, 1885 -

Rochester - N. Y.

Other side Please

She also suggests offering a copy of their History to every person who sends five new subscribers to double the National Citizen's bids.

letters.summarized4Sentences: Susan B. Anthony is asking Rachel to crowd all her engagements into the last two weeks of September and not to make any more engagements until after the Presidential Campaign. She mentions that there are many orators speaking everywhere with open doors and that she thinks it will be wise to give her time to working on the History of the W. R. Museum with Mrs. Norton. She also mentions that Mrs. May Wright Thompson wants to call an Ex. Com. meeting in New York City in October to talk over a plan to make their next Jan. Wash. Con. the best they can. Susan B. Anthony also mentions that Mrs. Stanton is now at leisure and in the mood of writing on the history and that it is her duty to go to Mrs. Stanton and make the most of the coming three months.

letters.summerized4Sentences: Susan is writing to Rachel about getting all of Perns?. history down to the year 1860- with Loyal League and Sanitary work of women there- during the War. Susan is sorry for the date Rachel can come to Tenafly. Susan will be in Providence the 10th & 12th to fill engagement for Mrs Stanton and possibly her Media, as she has given them choice between P. & me -- and in Boston, to fill another the 20th. Susan wants Rachel to make Phoebe remain at the Doctors till her joints get back to their normal state.

Susan talks about the progress of the History and mentions that Mrs. Stanton felt it best to offer Fredia the choice between Phoebe and Susan.

letters.dateOriginal: Office of the President, Rochester N.Y. May 12th, 1899
letters.summerized4Sentences: Susan B. Anthony discusses the cancellation of a Woman Suffrage meeting in London and her role in a sectional meeting. She also talks about the difficulty of organizing a Woman's Peace Meeting and the importance of Hearings before the Congressional Committees. Anthony expresses her belief that holding all of their Delegate Conventions in the city of Washington is the only possible method of securing representation from all the States and bringing their influence to bear upon the new men who are sent to Congress every two years.

letters.summarized4Sentences: Susan B. Anthony thanks Mrs. Elizabeth Smith Miller and her daughter for sending a check of $80 to cover her fourscore years. She mentions that she did not get to see Nannie much while in Washington due to her staying at a different hotel. Anthony believes that the convention and birthday celebrations were well managed, but acknowledges that there may have been some who were overlooked. She sends her love to Mrs. Miller and Nannie.

letters.summarized4Sentences: The letter was sent from Susan B. Anthony to Ellen H. Sheldon on November 28, 1880, from Tenafly, NJ. The letter discusses the importance of women's suffrage and the need for women to have a say in their government. Anthony also asks Sheldon to provide a report on Miss Cowyn's speech at Mrs. Mott's funeral and to describe how she was dressed. Additionally, Anthony mentions Mrs. Lockwood's positive outlook on the prospects of the Washington Convention and the cooperation between Sheldon, Mrs. Lockwood, and Phebe.

letters.summarized4Sentences: Susan is unsure which house to go to and is waiting for confirmation from the N.C. and D.D. She asks Rachel and Julia to try the Parker Winthrop and let her know if it's the right one. Mrs. Robinson received a message from Mrs. Gage saying it's at The Parker, so Susan telegraphed Pittsburgh. She is frustrated that the hotel hasn't been settled upon and every speaker hasn't been informed where to go.

letters.summarized4Sentences: Susan declines a generous offer to lend her $1000 for her history work, but instead asks to borrow from Rachel and Julia from time to time. She offers a 2% $1000 Government Bond as security. Susan will give notes to Rachel and Julia from time to time if they decide to loan her money. She asks them to keep the loan a secret from her sister.

letters.summarized4Sentences: Susan B. Anthony sends Rachel a package and asks for her opinion on who should compose the board of Trustees for the Standing Fund. She wonders if Rachel has received any of her talks. Susan expresses her frustration with the lack of power mothers have in the nation and hopes that women will gain control of conditions in peace and war. She ends the letter by asking Rachel to read the enclosed and send it on to Miss Shaw.

letters.summerized4Sentences: A friend of Susan's, Mrs. Eddy, passed away and left a will. Her man of business, Mr. C.R. Ransom, is the Executor and consulted with the author of the letter about her intentions. Mrs. Eddy left $80,000 and ordered it to be divided equally between Susan B. Anthony and Lucy Stone. The author of the letter advised Mrs. Eddy to give the sum to Susan outright.

She sent off advance sheets to the Boston and Chicago papers last Wednesday.

letters.summarized4Sentences: Susan B. Anthony writes to Mrs. Rachel Foster Avery about various matters, including sending a package to a French correspondent, Minnesota's delinquency, and Mrs. Alger Ketcham's invitation to the National Association. She also discusses the need for a National Press Manager and encloses a letter from Mrs. Elnora M. Babcock of Dunkirk. Anthony expresses her satisfaction with Mrs. Harper's work and the immense newspaper discussion she is starting throughout the country. She also mentions the ideal of having all of their different departments of work together in one city.

letters.summarized4Sentences: Wendell Phillips informs Susan B. Anthony that the suit against the will of Mr. Eddy has been withdrawn, which means that about $20,000 will be coming to her to use for the Women's Rights cause. Phillips advises Anthony to give the Executor a bond to refund if anything occurs prior to the payment date to close up all doubt and save all questions in case of her death. The result is mainly due to the Executor Mr. Ransom who has left no stone unturned and exercised wonderful ingenuity in securing this result.

letters.summarized4Sentences: William Loeb, Jr. sent a letter to Mrs. Ida Husted Harper on February 10, 1904, enclosing an invitation and ticket for Miss Anthony to enter the building by the south door. The letter was sent from the White House in Washington.

letters.summarized4Sentences: Susan is distressed that the P. Committee refused to pay Phebe the lecture fee and her postals never got to Susan until last night. She is worried that Phebe will back down on the Indiana lectures. Susan is also waiting for a package of U. W. S. paper and envelopes. She mentions that Mrs. Gage hasn't been able to get any of the Con. letters into the Feb. A. C.
